details.title: Reliability estimation in a generalized life-model with application to the Burr-XII

p: Ahmed A. Soliman (born 1957) received his M. S. in mathematics from Assiut University, Egypt, and Ph. D. in mathematical statistics from South Valley University, Egypt. His research interests are in statistical estimation and prediction.

details.abstract: Estimators of the reliability function in a GLM (generalized life model) are considered. The class of the GLM includes (among others) the Weibull, Pareto, Beta, Gompertz, and Rayleigh distribution. A proper general prior density and the predictive function for general class of distribution proposed by Al-Hussaini(1999) are used to obtain the exact estimate. Also, the Bayes estimates relative to symmetric loss function (quadratic loss), and asymmetric loss function (LINEX loss, and GE loss), are obtained. Comparisons are made between those estimators and the MLE applying to the Burr-XII model using the Bayes approximation due to Lindley. Monte Carlo simulation was used.

context.text: A proper general prior pdf and the predictive Cdf of the general class of distributions [1] are used to obtain the exact estimate of reliability function.

references.title: Bayesian estimation of the parameters, reliability and failure rate functions of the Burr type XII failure model

context.text:
Reference [2] suggests using the prior pdf:
\$h_1\$ is the \$\gamma\$ conjugate prior, when \$c\$ is known, and \$h_2(c)\$ is the gamma \$(\beta,\,\delta)\$ pdf.

Using the posterior distribution (7) with \$\varphi(\theta)\$ and \$\Psi(\theta)\$ as in (35), then from (17) and (29), \$R_{\rm BS}^*\$ for \$R\equiv R(t)\$ under an SE loss is:
 After setting: \$u(\theta)=(1+t^c)^{{-}k}\$ in (37), then the approximate Bayes estimate in (38) becomes:
 evaluated at (\$\mathhat{c}_{\rm ML},\,\mathhat{k}_{\rm ML}\$), where  the \$c_{\rm BS}^*\$ and \$k_{\rm BS}^*\$ can be obtained by setting \$u(\theta) = c\$ and \$k\$ in (37), respectively; the details are in [2].

For a given vector (\$\alpha =5,\,\beta =6,\,\gamma =4,\,\delta =3\$), generate \$c=6.25\$, \$k=3.55\$ from the prior pdf (31), as explained in [2]. (The generated values of \$c\$ and \$k\$ can be used as the true values.).

references.text: E. K. Al-Hussaini, Z. F. Jaheen, "Bayesian estimation of the parameters reliability and failure rate functions of the Burr type XII failure model", J. Statistical Computation and Simulation, vol. 41, pp. 31-40, 1992.

references.title: Bayesian approach to life testing and reliability estimation using asymmetric loss-function

context.text: However, such a restriction might be impractical; for example, in estimating reliability and failure rate functions, an overestimate is usually much more serious than an underestimate, in this case the use of symmetrical loss function might be inappropriate [3], [5].

references.title: Point estimation under asymmetric loss functions for left-truncated exponential samples

context.text: A useful asymmetric loss (LINEX loss function) was introduced in [24], and was widely in several papers, e.g., [4], [13], [14], [21], [29].

The Bayes estimator \$u_{\rm BL}^*\$ of \$u\$ under the LINEX loss function is the value \$\mathtilde{u}\$ which minimizes (19):
 provided that \${\rm E}_u[\exp (-a\cdot u)]\$ exists and is finite [4].

Another useful asymmetric loss function is the GE loss [4]:
 whose minimum occurs at \$\mathtilde{u}=u\$.
The problem of choosing the value of the shape parameter of the selected loss-function are discussed in [4].

references.text: R. Calabria, G. Pulcini, "Point estimation under asymmetric loss functions for left-truncated exponential samples", Communications in Statistics Theory and Methods, vol. 25, no. 3, pp. 585-600, 1996.

references.title: A Bayesian approach to reliability estimation using a loss function

context.text: However, such a restriction might be impractical; for example, in estimating reliability and failure rate functions, an overestimate is usually much more serious than an underestimate, in this case the use of symmetrical loss function might be inappropriate [3], [5].

links.abstract: A Bayesian estimate of reliability for the exponential case is developed which utilizes the basic notion of loss in estimation theory. Since the loss associated with overestimation is usually greater than the loss associated with underestimation of reliability, the loss function can be a useful tool. The loss function and prior distribution of reliability presented are sufficiently flexible to be compatible with many situations in which reliability estimates are require. When no prior informatio...

references.text: R. V. Canfield, "A Bayesian approach to reliability estimation using a loss function", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-19, pp. 13-16, 1970.

references.title: Discussion on D. V. Lindley's 1980 paper on approximate Bayesian methods

Other approximation forms, e.g., Laplace approximation and approximation form in [23], can be used to evaluate the ratio of integrals of the form (24); see [23].

references.title: Approximate Bayesian method

context.text: Approximate Bayes estimators using the well known Bayes approximation procedure [11] is considered.

Thus a simple approximation [11]via an asymptotic expansion of the ratio of 2 nontractable integrals, was chosen.22
For an English reference, see [[16], pp. 73-75].

references.text: D. V. Lindley, "Approximate Bayesian method", Trabajos de Estadistica, vol. 31, pp. 223-237, 1980.

references.title: Bayes estimation of the reliability function of normal distribution

context.text:
Under an SE loss, the Bayes estimator \$R^*(t)\$, of \$R(t)\$, at a mission time \$t\$ is the posterior mean:
 Using (7) and (9),
 Thus the Bayes estimator of \$R(t)\$ is the reliability function of the predictive distribution [18].
Under the SE loss (quadratic) function, the usual Bayes estimator of a given function of the parameters is the posterior mean of this function [18].

links.abstract: Bayes estimates of the survivor function of the s-normal distribution are obtained using the predictive distribution and some recent results on Bayes approximations due to Lindley. Monte Carlo simulation was used. These estimates have smaller rms error than that of their maximum likelihood counterparts. Except for large samples, the exact estimators based on the predictive distribution perform better than the Lindley approximate estimators.

references.text: S. K. Sinha, "Bayes estimation of the reliability function of normal distribution", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-34, pp. 360-362, 1985.

references.title: A note on the efficiency of Bayesian approximation

context.text: Reference [19] shows that up to the order of \$(n^{{-}2})\$, the Bayes estimate using the linear approximation (25) is more efficient than the MLE.

references.text: S. K. Sinha, A note on the efficiency of Bayesian approximation, 1987, Dept. of Statistics, University of Manitoba.

references.title: A function for size distribution of incomes

context.text: Reference [20]shows that the Burr-XII model has excellent properties for modeling the size distribution of incomes; [26] used the Burr-XII model to fit the life data in a medical study; [30] discusses the statistical and probabilistic properties of the Burr-XII distribution, and its relationship to other distributions used in reliability analyses.

references.text: S. K. Sinha, G. S. Moddola, "A function for size distribution of incomes", Econometrica, vol. 44, pp. 963-969, 1976.

references.title: Maximum likelihood methods for fitting the Burr Type XII distribution to life test data

context.text: Reference [20]shows that the Burr-XII model has excellent properties for modeling the size distribution of incomes; [26] used the Burr-XII model to fit the life data in a medical study; [30] discusses the statistical and probabilistic properties of the Burr-XII distribution, and its relationship to other distributions used in reliability analyses.

This example uses an example from [26] based on the failure times of certain electronic components and using type-II censoring; 30 components were involved in the life test, which was censored after 20 failures.

references.text: D. R. Wingo, "Maximum likelihood methods for fitting the Burr Type XII distribution to life test data", Biometrical J., vol. 25, pp. 77-81, 1983.
